channel.title: Bloomberg Politics
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: Starmer Makes Late Fishing Concession to Seal EU-UK Deal
item.description: British and European Union negotiators reached a deal overnight to strengthen their relationship after the UK agreed to extend fishing rights until 2038, according to people familiar with the discussions and documents seen by Bloomberg.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli, Alex Wickham, Jorge Valero

media:content.media:description: Fishermen gut freshly caught fish while trawling in the English Channel.

item.title: Germany Says Working on New Russia Sanctions in Ceasefire Push
item.description: Germany is working with allies on a new package of sanctions aimed at pressuring Russia to agree to a ceasefire in its war with Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Michael Nienaber

media:content.media:description: Burned out vehicles outside a shopping mall following a Russian drone attack on Kyiv, on May 4 Photographer: Sergei Supinsky/Getty Images

item.title: China Gave Pakistan Satellite Help, India Defense Group Says
item.description: China provided Pakistan with air defense and satellite support during its clash with India this month, according to a research group under India’s Ministry of Defence, suggesting that Beijing was more directly involved in the conflict than was previously disclosed.
item.dc:creator: Sudhi Ranjan Sen, Dan Strumpf

media:content.media:description: A motorcyclist rides past shattered glasses of a restaurant outside the Rawalpindi cricket stadium after an alleged drone was shot down in Rawalpindi on May 8, 2025. India and Pakistan accused each other on May 8 of carrying out waves of drone attacks, as deadly confrontations between the nuclear-armed foes drew global calls for calm. Pakistan's army said it shot down 25 Indian drones, while New Delhi accused Islamabad of launching overnight raids with "drones and missiles", and claimed it destroyed an air defence system in Lahore. (Photo by Aamir QURESHI / AFP) (Photo by AAMIR QURESHI/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Netanyahu Says Israel to Take Over All Gaza, Restart Aid Flows
item.description: Israel will take over the entire Gaza Strip, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said on Monday, as the military announced it would carry out an “unprecedented attack” on Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Alisa Odenheimer, Ethan Bronner, Galit Altstein

media:content.media:description: An Israeli tank manoeuvres in the Gaza Strip, seen from southern Israel, on May 19. Photographer: Ohad Zwigenberg/AP Photo

item.title: Romanian Centrist Beats Far-Right, Tusk Ally Ahead in Poland
item.description: Romania’s presidential election saw the centrist mayor of Bucharest defeat a far-right Donald Trump loyalist, while a nationalist finished a close second in Poland to set up a tight runoff on June 1.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu, Irina Vilcu

media:content.media:description: Nicusor Dan greets supporters following the first exit poll results, at an election night rally in Bucharest, Romania, on May 18, 2025. Photographer: Andrei Pungovschi/Getty Images

item.title: Three Votes and No Easy Way Forward for Europe
item.description: Welcome to Balance of Power, bringing you the latest in global politics. If you haven’t yet, sign up here.
item.dc:creator: Alan Crawford

media:content.media:description: Rafal Trzaskowski, mayor of Warsaw, center left, and his wife Malgorzata Trzaskowski during an election night rally in Sandomierz, Poland, on Sunday, May 18, 2025. Trzaskowski, the centrist Warsaw mayor, and Karol Nawrocki, a pro-Donald Trump nationalist, came neck-and-neck in the first round of Poland's presidential election, according to an exit poll, in a blow to the pro-European government. Photographer: Damian Lemanski/Bloomberg

item.title: Iran Says Its Uranium Enrichment Is ‘Absolutely Non-Negotiable’
item.description: Iran said its ability to enrich uranium was “absolutely non-negotiable” after US President Donald Trump’s special envoy repeated a demand that the Islamic Republic cease its production of the fissile material.
item.dc:creator: Arsalan Shahla

media:content.media:description: Technicians work inside a uranium conversion facility outside Isfahan, Iran. Photographer: Getty Images/Getty Images

item.title: Marcos Says He Is Open to Reconcile With the Duterte Family
item.description: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. said he’s willing to mend ties with the family of Vice President Sara Duterte, after candidates supported by his estranged deputy won more seats than expected during last week’s Senate election.
item.dc:creator: Cliff Harvey Venzon

media:content.media:description: Ferdinand Marcos Jr. during a campaign event in Manila on May 9.

item.title: Tanzania Opposition Says Democracy at Risk as Leader Faces Trial
item.description: Tanzania’s main opposition leader is facing treason charges months before presidential elections, a case that has heightened concerns about the state of democracy in the East African nation.
item.dc:creator: Helen Nyambura

media:content.media:description: Tundu Lissu speaks with his lawyers at the magistrate’s court in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania.

item.title: Euro-Area Inflation to Fall Below 2% on US Tariffs, EU Predicts
item.description: Euro-area inflation will fall below the European Central Bank’s target next year because of fallout from US trade policies, according to the European Commission.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber

media:content.media:description: The headquarters of the European Central Bank (ECB) beyond containers at a freight terminal in Frankfurt.

item.title: Japan Minister’s Brag About Free Rice Misfires Amid Surging Prices
item.description: Japan’s agriculture minister said he’d been inconsiderate after comments about his plentiful supply of free rice struck a nerve with the public, who face soaring prices in stores.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Hilton

media:content.media:description: A customer shops for rice at a supermarket in Koshigaya, Japan.

item.title: Polish Markets Get Hit After Race for President Tightens
item.description: Polish assets slipped after a stronger-than-expected showing by opposition populists in the first round of the presidential election, boding badly for the pro-European government and its centrist candidate.
item.dc:creator: Konrad Krasuski, Agnieszka Barteczko

media:content.media:description: Rafal Trzaskowski, mayor of Warsaw, center, waves a Polish flag during an election night rally in Sandomierz, Poland, on Sunday, May 18, 2025. Trzaskowski, the centrist Warsaw mayor, and Karol Nawrocki, a pro-Donald Trump nationalist, came neck-and-neck in the first round of Poland's presidential election, according to an exit poll, in a blow to the pro-European government.

item.title: Putin Heads Into Trump Call Confident That He Has Upper Hand
item.description: Vladimir Putin believes he has a strong hand ahead of a phone call Monday with Donald Trump as European leaders are trying to prevent the US president from rushing through a deal.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Drozdiak, Ben Sills

media:content.media:description: Vladimir Putin on May 16, in a photo released by Russian state media.

item.title: Indonesia Taps Singapore Traders in $12 Billion Pertamina Probe
item.description: Indonesian authorities have contacted a number of Singapore-based trading companies to request their cooperation in a $12 billion corruption probe involving state-owned oil giant PT Pertamina.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Lua, Serene Cheong, Chandra Asmara

media:content.media:description: The PT Pertamina logo.

item.title: China Tells Officials to Rein In Alcohol, Cigarette Spending
item.description: China reminded officials around the country to cut wasteful spending on travel, food and office space, adding to signs of an austerity push by President Xi Jinping as economic headwinds strain government budgets.
item.dc:creator: Philip Glamann

media:content.media:description: Xi Jinping Photographer: Pool/Getty Images

item.title: Portugal’s Prime Minister Wins Vote, Far-Right Party Surges
item.description: Portugal’s ruling center-right coalition won a snap election Sunday in a vote that saw the far-right surging, rocking the two-party system that’s dominated the country’s political life for 50 years.
item.dc:creator: Joao Lima, Henrique Almeida

media:content.media:description: Luis Montenegro during an election night rally in Lisbon, on May 18. Photographer: Zed Jameson/Bloomberg

item.title: China-US Tariff Truce Prompts Some Nations to Shift Tactics
item.description: China’s defiant stance in negotiating a tariff truce with the US has convinced some countries they need to take a tougher position in their own trade talks with the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Katia Dmitrieva

media:content.media:description: President Donald Trump during a Congressional resolution signing in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, on May 9.

item.title: France Touts Record Foreign Investment at Macron’s Annual Summit
item.description: French President Emmanuel Macron will tally €37 billion ($41.4 billion) in foreign investment at an annual gathering with business leaders, seeking to send an upbeat message as the slow-growing economy faces headwinds from US trade tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Tara Patel, William Horobin

media:content.media:description: Emmanuel Macron

item.title: Thailand Unveils Measures to Shield Firms From Trade War Fallout
item.description: Thailand will offer bigger tax incentives to small and medium businesses at risk of being squeezed by US tariff threats, as the Southeast Asian nation unveiled a raft of measures to minimize the blow to its economy from the trade war.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: Bangkok Port.

item.title: Thailand, Indonesia Pledge to Boost Trade as Strategic Partners
item.description: Thailand and Indonesia pledged to boost trade and investment and cooperate on cyber scam and drug trafficking crackdowns, as Southeast Asia’s two biggest economies elevated ties to a strategic partnership.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat, Chandra Asmara

media:content.media:description: Prabowo Subianto, left, and Paetongtarn Shinawatra in Bangkok on May 19. Photographer: Lillian Suwanrumpha/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: France Asks Airlines to Cut 15% of Paris-Orly Flights Monday
item.description: France’s civil aviation regulator asked airlines to cut 15% of flights at Paris-Orly airport on Monday as authorities continue to repair air traffic control systems.
item.dc:creator: Francois De Beaupuy, Jenny Che

media:content.media:description: Passengers in the departures hall at Paris-Orly Airport, operated by Aeroports de Paris, in Paris, France, on Tuesday, Feb. 27, 2024. Air France-KLM report earnings on Feb. 29.

item.title: Ishiba Rebuffs Tax Cut Demands With Greek Debt Comparison
item.description: Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba rebuffed calls for tax cuts saying that the nation’s financial conditions are worse than Greece’s.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

item.title: Trump Tax Bill Advances After GOP Deal for Faster Medicaid Cuts
item.description: A key House committee advanced President Donald Trump’s giant tax and spending package after Republican hardliners won agreement from party leaders to speed up cuts to Medicaid health coverage.
item.dc:creator: Emily Birnbaum, Jarrell Dillard, Steven T. Dennis

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump Photographer: Bonnie Cash/UPI

item.title: Mini ‘Sell America’ Trade Revived After Moody’s Downgrades US
item.description: Investors faced yet another bumpy start to the trading week with US assets coming under fresh pressure, although it’s mounting concern over American debt rather than tariffs generating the volatility this time.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Semenova, Carmen Reinicke, Anya Andrianova

media:content.media:description: A trader works on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Thursday, May 15, 2025. US stocks were on pace to snap a three-day winning streak Thursday, driven by declines in technology, energy and retailers as traders assessed a slew of mixed economic figures.

item.title: Japan’s Ishiba Says Won’t Fixate on US Trade Talk Time Limits
item.description: Japan won’t compromise its national interests in trade talks with the US by fixating on time limits, Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba said, signaling Tokyo isn’t rushing into an agreement.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

media:content.media:description: Shigeru Ishiba Photographer: Anna Rose Layden/UPI

item.title: Authorities Identify Suspect in Palm Springs Fertility Clinic Explosion
item.description: A 25-year-old man the FBI believes was responsible for an explosion that ripped through a Southern California fertility clinic left behind “anti-pro-life” writings before carrying out an attack investigators called terrorism, authorities said Sunday.

media:content.media:description: Investigators document the scene at the front of the American Reproductive Centers fertility clinic following a bomb blast in Palm Springs, California, on May 17, 2025.

item.title: Japan PM Ishiba’s Support Falls, No Ouster Seen Before July
item.description: Support for Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba’s government weakened, according to public opinion surveys published by major Japanese news organizations over the weekend, although it remains unlikely he’ll be ousted before a national election in July.
item.dc:creator: Alastair Gale

media:content.media:description: Shigeru Ishiba Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

item.title: South Korean Election Favorite Sees No Need to Rush for US Deal
item.description: South Korea’s leading presidential candidate Lee Jae-myung said there’s no need to rush into an early agreement in trade negotiations with the US, criticizing the interim government for what he called its hasty engagement with the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae-myung Photographer: Woohae Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: Milei Wins Big in Buenos Aires City Vote, Dethroning Macri
item.description: Javier Milei struck at the heart of his former ally’s biggest bastion of support and came out victorious in the city of Buenos Aires, cementing his hold on Argentina’s political right months before pivotal midterm elections.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Tobias

media:content.media:description: Javier Milei Photographer: Emiliano Lasalvia/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Warsaw Mayor to Face Populist in Polish Presidential Runoff
item.description: The mayor of Warsaw was poised for a narrow win over a pro-Donald Trump nationalist in the first round of Poland’s presidential election that is critical for the pro-European government’s agenda to undo years of populist rule.
item.dc:creator: Wojciech Moskwa, Natalia Ojewska

media:content.media:description: Rafal Trzaskowski during an election night rally in Sandomierz, Poland, on Sunday.
